Charlie Jeffery:"I've stuck my neck out as Vice-Chancellor"

20/02/2022

The Vice-Chancellor speaks about strikes and the University's response to Covid-19

Image by University of York

By Ed Halford

Over 50,000 university staff started their industrial action nationwide this week and the University of Yorkâ€™s Vice Chancellor Charlie Jeffery used the opportunity to speak with Nouse to call on all parties to put forward a â€œset of ideas onto the table so they can be discussed.â€ Recently, the UCU (University and College Union) shared proposals which have sought to avert the strikes, suggesting that Jefferyâ€™s opinion that all sides need to be aware of â€œthe distance which needs to be bridgedâ€ has resonated. Unless the dispute is resolved, staff will be participating in strikes from Monday 14 to Friday 18 February, on Monday 21 and Tuesday 22 February and on Monday 28 February, Tuesday 1 and Wednesday 2 March.

Jeffery said he â€œrecognised that students have had a really tough timeâ€ but insisted that his approach has always â€œbeen to do what we can to minimise the impact.â€ As a Vice Chancellor who wishes to be perceived as â€œpretty invisible to studentsâ€, behind closed doors Jeffery wants students to know that he is fighting their corner. Jeffery recalled: â€œIâ€™ve stuck my neck out as Vice-Chancellor which other Vice-Chancellors havenâ€™t been happy with, particularly by criticising the approach of the pension fund.â€

Going forward, the VC said: â€œI am encouraging USU locally to get a proposal into the mix â€“ I heard some ideas about 10 days ago but these have not yet been put into the formal process.â€ The UCU put forward new pension proposals on 26 January as part of efforts to prevent industrial action and on 10 February the USS trustee confirmed the unionâ€™s proposals were â€œviable and implementable.â€ The trustee therefore reported that there is â€œno impediment to implementation of alternative compromise proposals put forward by UCU.â€ The likelihood of a resolution bringing the forthcoming strikes to an early end is unclear.

Nouse pressed the VC to guarantee students that their summer examinations would not include content affected by the strikes. Jeffery was unable to promise students that disruption will not compromise their ability to complete assessments, although he did assert that â€œIf something is not taught it canâ€™t be examined.â€ Expanding further on this point, the VC suggested that decisions relating to examinations remain at the discretion of the Exceptional Circumstances Committees. Jeffery said the necessary steps to judge whether content should be examined include asking â€œCan the material be delivered in another wayâ€ and â€œCan an alternative way of learning be delivered for that subject.â€

A major responsibility of the Vice-Chancellor is setting and reviewing the Universityâ€™s Covid-19 precautions and Nouse therefore asked why the University had not followed the governmentâ€™s lead in lifting the â€˜Plan Bâ€™ restrictions. Jeffery said: â€œWe have been careful to weigh things up on the basis of our own evidence and analysis.â€ The restrictions were extended because of the â€œlocal circumstancesâ€, with student cases peaking at 238 on 25 January. The current measures will continue to stay in place until Friday 11 February, although the VC hinted these could soon be relaxed due to the number of cases dropping to below 20â€™.

In the past, the Vice-Chancellor has argued students received â€œa good experienceâ€ in terms of their online education during the last academic year. Jeffery was not willing to accept the suggestion that he was out of touch with studentsâ€™ experience of education during the lockdowns and heaped praise on his colleagues for their â€œwonderful examples of being innovative.â€ As the government has gradually eased restrictions, Jeffery highlights that â€œWe have offered more in person than many universities have. â€œWe have been at the forefront of delivering as much in person as we possibly could.â€

Students forced to self-isolate last year became familiar with the â€˜brown paper bag food parcelsâ€™ which were neither nutritious nor value for money. When asked for an explanation as to why students in isolation were offered unhealthy and inadequate meals the VC said: â€œWe were thrust into a situation nobody has ever been in before. â€œWe had to improvise very quickly and at that first stage perhaps we werenâ€™t providing the nutritional depths we should have been.â€ However, the VC pointed to the Universityâ€™s existing deal with Morrisons as evidence that provisions for those isolating on and off campus has improved.

Jeffery said: â€œOne of the really remarkable things was doing a deal with Morrisons. It was difficult at that moment to get supermarket deliveries, but we persuaded Morrisons to set up a special system for students in York.â€ Inspired by the University of York, the scheme has since been rolled out nationwide.

The University of York has recently promoted the education it provides as existing for â€œpublic good.â€ The University of Yorkâ€™s website boasts of the institutionâ€™s founders having a â€œstrong social purposeâ€, and Jeffery drew on how the Universityâ€™s â€œcollaborative approachâ€ to the pandemic demonstrated this.

Jeffery revealed: â€œFrom the first cases in York, we were in the meeting rooms with public health officials from the council and the city leader.â€ Everyone involved from the council to the University had a â€œshared purposeâ€ and â€œtrusted each other.â€ The Vice-Chancellor was proud the University was home to â€œone of the big community centres in the cityâ€ and the opening of a PCR testing centre on Wentworth Way can be explained by â€œworking collaboratively from the very outset.â€ The Vice-Chancellor emphasised that giving back to residents in York was a â€œvery obvious thing in the end, we had a big sports hall.â€ Part of the â€œcollaborative approachâ€ was inviting local schools such as Fulford school to take advantage of the Universityâ€™s testing centre on West Campus.

Nouse asked Charlie Jeffery whether there was a main message he would like to communicate to students and he said the following: â€œWe will do what we can to minimise the effects of industrial actionâ€ and â€œI would like to call on all parties in the dispute to find a resolution.â€
